awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Navigation Independent Relative  Positioning System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve of aerospace exploration.  In aviation, the capability of the Navigation Relative Positioning System (NIRPS) working with GPS as a reliable interoperable mutual backup system will significantly reduce the need for ground control, hence providing flight safety and the ability to reduce the massive cost of ground support services.  In space applications, NIRPS will significantly improve guidance and control of many space operations, from Low Earth Orbit to Beyond Earth Orbit space missions. It will enhance autonomous rendezvous, improve accuracy of position sensing, and increase the capability of docking without humans in the loop. It will significantly reduce dependence on ground-based tracking, ranging, trajectory/orbit/attitude determination and maneuver planning support functions, and complexity of the flight control algorithms. By continuously holding position information on trajectory, NIRPS will provide programmable capabilities to allow the spacecraft to act independently from ground control, devising real-time actions in response to environmental conditions as well rejecting possible hijacking attempts. NIRPS will enable classes of missions which would not be previously possible.

The proposed project will address the problems of aerospace navigation by providing onboard reliable real time autonomous cybersecure navigation for aerospace applications. Due to the latency and instability of inertial navigation, aerospace navigation relies on GPS, beacons, and flight/mission control systems. Contrary to inertial navigation utilizing forces of spinning mass or propagation of light inside rotational media, the proposed NIRPS utilizes collinear displacement of the inertial frame in relation to the independent propagation of light within. The Phase I project encompasses the feasibility of deploying photonics methods of fabrication of the NIRPS key component, the Non-Inertial Velocity Detector (NIVD). Silicon photonics is becoming the leading technology for Photonic Integrated Circuits (PICs) due to large-scale integration, low cost, and high-volume production enabled by the Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) fabrication process. In this Phase, we will research materials and their possible interactions in varying environmental conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report
NSF SBIR Phase I

Fed. Agency to which report is submitted: 4900
Fed Award ID: # 1936558
Award Title: Navigation Independent Relative Positioning System (NIRPS)
Recipient Awardee: Non-Inertial Navigation Technology, LLC
Funds: $215,181
Project/Grant Period: 11/25/2019 ? 06/29/2020
PI Name: Val Parker

The NSF SBIR Navigation Independent Relative Positioning System (NIRPS) project was established with the goal of developing and deploying advanced devices of onboard navigation to assure reliable and secure flights of aerospace platforms.
Phase I of the NIRPS project was dedicated to the research of the materials and methods suitable for the Photonic Microchip fabrication of the Non-Inertial Velocity Detector (NIVD), the key element of the system. Transformation of Electronics into Photonics became the driving trend of the Century that encompass every part of worldwide industries from energy production to high-speed communications. Along these lines, the conversion of sensing/detecting devices from electronics into photonics opens great opportunities for the manufacturing of complex photonic systems using the well-developed complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) technology.
Utilization of known attractive advantages of CMOS technology of Electronic microchips fabrication made it extremely desirable for the fabrication of the NIVD Photonic microchips. The application of Silicon Fabrication methods for the photonic microcircuit is a relatively new area of development with many unknowns and a limited library of the ready to fabricate circuit?s elements. The critical area in such conversion entails the research in resolving the issues of optoelectronic coexistence, i.e. the ability to successfully operate light, within permissible ranges of losses and distortions, under given configurations of the optoelectronic circuits. In this respect, NIRPS Phase I project was directed toward resolving the problems of the excess of heat and noise of the photonic interface on the Silicon substrate. The research performed during Phase I of the project has provided critical system analysis in the development of the photonic signal modulator, the key active component of the circuitry.The series of actual and computer-simulated research was performed to outline the functional parameters of the modulator.
The crucial work was performed on an exploration of the thermo-optic modulator using the finite element method (FEM) implemented in COMSOL Multiphysics26 (See Heating Coil Design Image). As the result of the research, the design of the modulator where the waveguide is heated laterally by placing the adjacent resistive heaters separated by spacers, was chosen for the fabrication.While such a scheme might involve complex nanofabrication (though within the capabilities of most foundries), the simulation shows about 80% improvement in modulation bandwidth can be achieved.

The major Practical Outcome of this Phase I R&D work has manifested itself in the results of the research that open ways for the NIVD fabrication using the (CMOS) technology advantages.The customized Photonic NIVD Microchips will have game-changing advantageous such as low size, weight, power consumption, and cost (SWaP-C); reduced complexity of the circuits; high density of logic functions on a chip; and high noise immunity.

The NIVD fabrication and integration into the NIRPS system as well as the systems evaluation in the Aerospace environment will be accomplished during Phase II of the NIRPS Project.The successful results of Phase I research have become a steppingstone in the progress of finding the needed solutions for the safety and reliability of Aerospace flights.

The deployment of NIRPS systems will revolutionize the Aerospace navigation, providing reliable continuous onboard Cybersecure navigation for all types of crafts and applications. This innovative and high impact development in the guidance, navigation, and flight control technologies, is that what Aerospace is seeking in support of its current and future requirements.

The Broader Impact of the utilization of the NIRPS devices, as the GPS backup systems, will strengthen national resilience, providing secure and reliable Position Navigation and Timing (PNT) services to the United States National Critical Infrastructure. The successful NIRPS development will eliminate any possibilities similar to the 9/11 disasters, providing the ability to reach chosen destinations, even as far as distant stars, and safely navigate home.
